body:
Everything Apple makes has been shit for the last 2 decades. The problem is they decided they wanted to control everyone so they removed most features and took away most personal settings. With Apple, Apple owns your device, not you. They literally make you pay 10x more for something that's half as capable. Windows was always the better alternative until recently with windows 10 they're starting to go that route too. I've always liked the windows and linux UI better too, I'm not sure what all the fuss about Macs is.

Also *every* modern UI sucks, reason being because everyone is going for that ugly, dull, boring "flat" look which makes no sense now that we have more powerful machines. And like I said they took away all the ways to change anything too. The only solution now is linux with custom themes, and even those are breaking now with newer versions of renderers, so if it wasn't made in the last year you'll probably have to re-make it.

post.body:
I went to Linux a few years ago as a Windows refugee, knowing that every day that I spent learning how to tweak Windows further was a day wasted in a constant uphill battle just for myself against Microsoft. Linux really didn't appeal to me at first, as I noticed inconsistencies with its UI and the difficulty to pull off certain tasks.

Since I always had a Windows 10 laptop given for work, I never had to be reminded about how bad Windows was (and is) for productivity. Today however, starting at new company, I've been relieved from W10 with a new a Macbook Pro - the latest model, something m1 Big Sur. It's a great design, got a great keyboard, and I'm quite fond of some of the gestures.

But HO-LY are some of the Mac UI/UX inconsistencies never given their spotlight:

* Setup had text overlapping a spinning icon
* Keyboard shortcuts for default apps have me straining fingers (have you SEEN the browser tab switching shortcuts?)
* Resizing windows in default apps permanently makes text stay at "..."
* Terminal can't be closed with Ctrl^C, or Exit
* Majority of actions require mouse/gesture, and take half a second with animations
* Alt-tab can focus closed apps
* None of this is easily customizable
* Plugging in a keyboard makes trackpad gestures unbearable
* You can't do (some parts of) application installs in parallel

And I'm leaving out the design issues that are just my unfamiliarity bias, like the fact that you *need* to use a mouse to navigate around.

I never gave Mac a serious shot before so I wasn't aware of these things compared to Linux, and always assumed it was pretty good, but it shocks me that one of the most user-friendly devices has issues that not even Linux has.

I genuinely believe at this point and time a proper KDE setup has better UX for developers, kids and just about anyone other than computer illiterates alike. Mac has some great features, but is not polished like I always thought.

Anyways, this is a mini-rant break between going through my checklist of things I want to set up for the Mac.
post.body_html:
I went to Linux a few years ago as a Windows refugee, knowing that every day that I spent learning how to tweak Windows further was a day wasted in a constant uphill battle just for myself against Microsoft. Linux really didn't appeal to me at first, as I noticed inconsistencies with its UI and the difficulty to pull off certain tasks.

Since I always had a Windows 10 laptop given for work, I never had to be reminded about how bad Windows was (and is) for productivity. Today however, starting at new company, I've been relieved from W10 with a new a Macbook Pro - the latest model, something m1 Big Sur. It's a great design, got a great keyboard, and I'm quite fond of some of the gestures.

But HO-LY are some of the Mac UI/UX inconsistencies never given their spotlight:

  • Setup had text overlapping a spinning icon
  • Keyboard shortcuts for default apps have me straining fingers (have you SEEN the browser tab switching shortcuts?)
  • Resizing windows in default apps permanently makes text stay at "..."
  • Terminal can't be closed with Ctrl^C, or Exit
  • Majority of actions require mouse/gesture, and take half a second with animations
  • Alt-tab can focus closed apps
  • None of this is easily customizable
  • Plugging in a keyboard makes trackpad gestures unbearable
  • You can't do (some parts of) application installs in parallel

And I'm leaving out the design issues that are just my unfamiliarity bias, like the fact that you need to use a mouse to navigate around.

I never gave Mac a serious shot before so I wasn't aware of these things compared to Linux, and always assumed it was pretty good, but it shocks me that one of the most user-friendly devices has issues that not even Linux has.

I genuinely believe at this point and time a proper KDE setup has better UX for developers, kids and just about anyone other than computer illiterates alike. Mac has some great features, but is not polished like I always thought.

Anyways, this is a mini-rant break between going through my checklist of things I want to set up for the Mac.
post.title: Mac UI/UX is NOT what people think it is

body:
1. No, you have to earn some of them. Same with some of the theory channels and other stuff.

2. No, it got that way because the admins became friends with a particular clique of users and made them the moderators of every subreddit. There was a time when the only subreddits were the defaults. Take a look at the moderators of subreddits like /r/help, it's the exact same thing they're doing on ruqqus.

3. If a user fixes a message then it's fixed, why does it need modding? And *maybe* the admins should be able to see deleted and pre-edited messages, but definitely not mods because they're just regular users, or should be even though the admins treat them as special.

4. "Guild limits" isn't going to stop anything. These power user cabals work together. They will simply spread GM duties across multiple people. Plus it just shows that the admins are biased and can't be trusted to make objective decisions.

5. How so? What's so wrong about literally everyone on the site other than 6-8 users?

6. No they're not, because it's a completely unfair system *and* it will result in the same future as reddit. Do you really want ruqqus to just half fix exactly *one* problem reddit has and keep all the rest?

  4. "Guild limits" isn't going to stop anything. These power user cabals work together. They will simply spread GM duties across multiple people. Plus it just shows that the admins are biased and can't be trusted to make objective decisions.

  6. No they're not, because it's a completely unfair system and it will result in the same future as reddit. Do you really want ruqqus to just half fix exactly one problem reddit has and keep all the rest?

parent.body:
1. I agree with you on the slowmode and dyno(the only rules/limits I've seen them "break")
2. They have to be allowed into gated channels in order to moderate those channels
3. Admins names are at the top of the server so users know who to report bugs to and DM for issues/exploits
4. Of course they listen to the "6-8 people" more they're trusted users
5. They need a private chat room to talk about strikes and bans, users would get upset if mods talked about banning someone or new rules being made in the open
6. The "junior admins" would've just been moderators to the site which will be a needed thing in the future *anyways*
7. The focus group is a group of users able to quickly reply to changes that the admins trust to be unbias and honest, it will grow with time and I see 0 issues with the admins having a focus group of their choosing
8. The only "special treatment" on Ruqqus you've given me is that they were picked as GMs on admin's(mainly kek) guilds.  I don't see this as a problem whatsoever, GMs are able to choose who they want to be GMs alongside them so admins should be allowed to do the same.  They won't be able to make default mods with this they just want to be able to have their own guilds with people they trust taking care of them.
9. I can't say very much about the coding but again, communication has a lot to do with it.  Seq is probably the one most in touch with the admins over issues so I can see why he's the go-to but again, I can't say much because I don't know coding and I've only looked at github once before realizing I had no clue what 90% of the stuff on there was

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

body:
> You aren't active on discord, thats literally the biggest problem.

Neither are the other users on the first list.

> Yea and you have a **very high** sub count as well. There are always going to be people who have it better because of timings, influence, alts etc. That doesn't mean what you're doing is bad.

I know, so why do all these nobodies have so many more than we do? It's literally like 4x as many in some cases, that doesn't make sense. And a user who just made a post saying "hi" and nothing else got as many as me, something's definitely not right about that. And all of @eagle's posts are like 100-200 upvotes in addition to the unexplainable amount of followers. I've never heard of them before eiher.

body:
> Hmm. How often do you participate in the comment sections of guilds not owned by you or you are GM of?

Well whenever I see a post I might have something to say on (which is a lot).

> It seems half of my subscribers did so because of comments and or replies I made.

I don't think I've even gotten a single one that way. People just don't like me for some reason. I never get invited to anything made by users here either, even when everyone else I know does.

> Of course regularly posting good content helps too?

I'm well-known for posting good non-political content. But despite this neither my guilds nor my account grow very much at all. Yet yours do at an insane rate. What's wrong with me, is it something I can change or just yet another thing I have to live with?

> You need to advertise yourself more.

?

> found a mean exploit

It was nothing. All you could do was half-herald posts in another guild. Everything else failed to go through. A real exploit is something like the stuff @sfrohne finds all the time, like infinite coins and seeing deleted posts. She finds them just by skimming through the code most times, and always spots them even though they're nearly impossible to catch, and is not even a programmer!

  8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

  9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's no one in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And all the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

post.body:
There's a lot of accounts on here that are very active and as such have a lot of followers. Usually it's like 20-45. Almost all the people I recognize as power users are in this group. However there's also a group of accounts that is mostly newer than those, posts less...and the top ones have about 70-120 followers (as many as the admins)!

This doesn't really make any sense to me. Here's a list for reference. I excluded admins and novelty accounts:

1. @eagle 110 subscribers, last active one month ago

2. @carpathianflorist 77 subscribers

3. @NeonRevolt 73 subscribers, last active 2 months ago

4. @Inaki 31 subscribers...1 post 5 months ago and zero comments??!!

5. @AngstKitten 20 subscribers, last posted 1 month ago and only comments a couple times per month

6. @Sentient 18 subscribers, last active 3 months ago

For comparison, here's a list of ones I think actually make sense. Notice the huge gap in followers between these and the unexplained ones:

1. @stars_in_blue_major 41 subscribers

2. @TrumpVoter1 32 subscribers (private profile which may cause a small drop)

3. @CrystalVulpine 31 subscribers

4. @LlamaBean 23 subscribers

5. @Meguminnnn 23 subscribers (seems a tiny bit excessive because he's not *that* active but that could just be luck)

6. @AsininePorcupine 20 subscribers

7. @no_chill 20 subscribers

8. @VILLAIN 19 subscribers

9. @Bidpots 17 subscribers

What's also weird is how big the gap is. There's **no one** in the 45-65 range. It jumps immediately from 41 all the way to 73. And *all* the ones in the 70-120 range are these unexplained cases.

I really don't see how this works. I've never even heard of many of the ones on the first list, all the power users are on the second one. So I'm not really sure what's going on here. Anyone have any guesses?

body:
> but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

* Slowmode

* Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

* Admins let them break the rules a lot

* Admins put their names at the very top of the server

* Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

* Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

* Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

* Most of them were let into the focus group.

> I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

> Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

> Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

> But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.
body_html:
but dyno is a bitch about that so it's hard to set up.

That's not the only thing though:

  • Slowmode

  • Ability to participate in gated channels they haven't earned the rules for

  • Admins let them break the rules a lot

  • Admins put their names at the very top of the server

  • Admins listen to them more and have a private chat room with them

  • Admins originally planned on making them junior admins on the actual site too

  • Admins only let them GM their guilds or basically anything.

  • Most of them were let into the focus group.

I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod

And is that not a problem to you?

Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod after he had helped so much.

Cap doesn't just let anyone help him. He only picks a few people he thinks are "worthy" enough and everyone else is pretty much warded off.

Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient

Luk is a GM on +Technology and a discord mod. Ruq is part of the focus group and a discord mod. I believe Nova and/or Sentient GM a guild or two as well.

But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.

And the other things I listed. But just the fact that they always pick the exact same people for everything hints that they are extremely biased and respecters of persons and are starting to form a DefaultMods-like mindset.

I've only seen Angst and Megu get "special treatment" on Ruqqus as a discord mod, Seq gets "special treatment" but that's because he constantly works with Cap on issues and became a mod *after* he had helped so much.  I don't see Ruq, Luk, Nova, or Sentient getting any special treatment.  But the "special treatment" on Ruqqus just seems to be that they're allowed to GM alongside the admins, which I see no issues with.
